data.title: Octaves!
data.solution:
i, n = gets.split.map &:to_i
notes = gets.split
keyboard = %w(C C# D D# E F F# G G# A A# B)
notes.map! { |item|
  base = item[0]
  up = item[1] == "#" ? "#" : ""
  height = up == "#" ? item[2..-1] : item[1..-1]
  height = height.to_i
  new = keyboard.index(base + up) + n
  height += new / keyboard.size if keyboard.size <= new || 0 > new
  "#{keyboard[new % keyboard.size]}#{height}"
}
puts notes.join " "
data.statement:
In music, notes can be represented as letters. The seven notes are <<C, D, E, F, G, A, B>> (in order).
An optional <<#>> can exist after the letter. <<#>> means one semitone higher. For example, <<A#>> is one semitone higher than <<A>>. However there is no <<E#>> or <<B#>> (the next semitone higher than <<E>> is <<F>>).
The seven keys repeat . A number after the letter and the optional <<#>> represents which octave (how high) the note is. For example, <<D5>> is 4 octaves higher than <<D1>>. 

In short, the form of a note is represented as <<NOTE>>(letter) <<#>>(optional) <<HEIGHT>>(integer)

A part of the keyboard is like this:
... <<C0 C#0 D0 D#0 E0 F0 F#0 G0 G#0 A0 A#0 B0 C1 C#1 D1 D#1>> ...

Given a list of [[i]] notes [[notes]] and an integer [[shift]], return the resulting list of notes after pitching each of the notes [[shift]] semitones higher.

Example:
<<2 2>>
<<C1 A#3>>

C1 go up by 2 semitones: C#1, then D1
A#3 go up by 2 semitones: B3, then C4

testCases.title: Negative
testCases.testOut: C2 A3 A#3 G#5 D5 G0

testCases.title: Validator 2
testCases.testOut: A1 G5 G#3 B4 C6 E1

testCases.title: Large increment
testCases.testOut: E4 F4 F#5 G5 G#6 A6 B7 C#7

testCases.title: Validator 3
testCases.testOut: A#3 B3 C1 C#5 D6 A6 F#7 C7

testCases.title: Nothing happens
testCases.testOut: G1 G#1 A1 A#1 B1 C0 C#0 D0 D#0 E0

testCases.title: Validator 4
testCases.testOut: D#0 E0 F0 F#0 G0 G#0 A0 A#0 B0 C1 C#1 D1

data.constraints:
1 < [[i]] < 40
-60 < [[shift]] < 60
0 <= height of any note <= 8

Each item in [[notes]] is guaranteed to be a valid note in form of letter + number or letter + # + number.
data.stubGenerator:
read N:int shift:int
loopline N note:word(10)
write pitched notes
data.inputDescription:
<<Line 1:>> Two space separated integers [[i]] and [[shift]] (shift may be negative)
<<Line 2:>> A list of [[i]] space separated strings, each representing one [[note]].
data.outputDescription: The pitched [[notes]], separated by single space.

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

In music, notes can be represented as letters. The seven notes are C, D, E, F, G, A, B (in order).
An optional # can exist after the letter. # means one semitone higher. For example, A# is one semitone higher than A. However there is no E# or B# (the next semitone higher than E is F).
The seven keys repeat . A number after the letter and the optional # represents which octave (how high) the note is. For example, D5 is 4 octaves higher than D1.

In short, the form of a note is represented as NOTE(letter) #(optional) HEIGHT(integer)

A part of the keyboard is like this:
... C0 C#0 D0 D#0 E0 F0 F#0 G0 G#0 A0 A#0 B0 C1 C#1 D1 D#1 ...

Given a list of i notes notes and an integer shift, return the resulting list of notes after pitching each of the notes shift semitones higher.

Example:
2 2
C1 A#3

C1 go up by 2 semitones: C#1, then D1
A#3 go up by 2 semitones: B3, then C4
Input
Line 1: Two space separated integers i and shift (shift may be negative)
Line 2: A list of i space separated strings, each representing one note.
Output
The pitched notes, separated by single space.
Constraints
1 < i < 40
-60 < shift < 60
0 <= height of any note <= 8

Each item in notes is guaranteed to be a valid note in form of letter + number or letter + # + number.
Example
Input
4 2
C1 B2 E3 A#3
Output
D1 C#3 F#3 C4
